pros: One of the standout aspects of working as a TA at UC Denver is the supportive and collaborative environment. review_title: School Of Medicine Data Analyst- Gotta love what you do and not for the money
job_title: IT Principal Professional in Aurora, CO
pros: - Fulfilling work- improving patient lives through better outcomes, fewer complications, etc., assisting clinicians in moving towards better data literacy, and all those rewarding situations. - Benefits are reasonable compared to the private sector but seem average for Universities (Compared to the only benefits I have read up on at Uni of Washington and Uni of Utah, both of which seem to be better). - Independence to work and get work done. I am given a bunch of trust and freedom, which is nice - Lots of potential for personal development - Clinicians I have worked with have been a delight to be on projects with. - Campus is beautiful - Tech Stack can be almost anything you want it to be, which is really fun when you work the entire data lifecycle. - Work/Life balance is great (for the majority of the time) - There are small yearly merit increases (which help people keep up with inflation, depending on the year).
cons: - Pay, obviously. It will always be VERY low compared to the private sector. With a few job opportunities looked into - including benefits, data people are still grossly underpaid comparatively. It can be frustrating seeing friends in the private sector making money hand over fist, and I can't even afford central a/c apartments if I want to live in Denver (while following financial wellness rules of thumb). - Little negotiating for low-level people. It is a double-edged sword in that HR told me it is all a formula- Years of Experience + Education + Job Code. So not positive or negative. It is what it is. It is nice knowing your coworker is getting paid the same (all inputs being equal) besides the small yearly merit raises. - Flat Admin Organizations means you top out very fast, Job Code wise. Once you are a Principal, the only way to keep going up is to become a manager. This sucks in the IT world because, as a Data Analyst currently, I know there should be higher job codes to shoot for (DBA, Data Scientist, Architect, etc.), but from my understanding, those job codes don't exist (Those people exist, though. My current thought is those positions are outside the typical job code structure)—so no pay bumps and no incentive to shoot for the next rung in the data world. - Parking on Campus (Cost vs. how close you are to your building), but I don't know of a University where that isn't an issue. - How siloed data sources are and trying to get access to them is exceptionally frustrating - No encompassing data culture. I don't know many SoM data people. I know they exist, but there aren't opportunities for us to connect.

review_title: Stay Away From the CU School of Dental Medicine
pros: Health insurance benefits are sufficient.
cons: Extreme micromanagement, outdated processes, toxic culture, low pay, and frankly they do not care about the well being of employees. Stay far away from the school of dental medicine. Another former employee review put it perfectly: “CU Anschutz is a huge campus with several departments, and I found it interesting that the dental school has not yet been mentioned on glassdoor. My ratings and comments are only in regards to the dental school. There is a high amount of employee turnover from newer employees (2 years or less) trying to come in and make a difference. I believe it is because the bulk of the existing staff and faculty have been there for 4 years to decades, and are stuck doing things "the way they have always been done". They are reluctant to hire new employees. They don't want to be questioned on their out-dated way of doing things. Instead, they find someone internal within the dental school who has already drunk the kool-aid. They want "yes" people. The culture is toxic, and they applaud those who push others way around. There is a lot of bullying here by those with power and are liked by the deans. Once you get on one of the deans' side, you are bullet proof, even if you cut people down daily.”

Something you might expect to turn around in two days can take two months or more. I knew full time professional employees here who spent much of their days doing grad school work, freelance or just watching YouTube. Pay is livable but not great. If you want to settle down into a very cushy job this could be perfect for you but if you like to be challenged and be productive you'll go crazy here. 

Also, lots of people are nice but there are some massive egos who are openly insulting, but that's standard in higher ed jobs.

review_title: Compassionate leaders, though it is still a business
job_title: Professional Research Assistant in Aurora, CO
pros:
I was a student working at the Department of Medicine here (Anschutz campus). I was a workaholic, despite only being available two days a week. Three years later, I am a recent grad from this institution that is working full-time for the first time, during a pandemic. 

My connections here started small. Since then, I have encountered dozens of compassionate and dedicated individuals, leadership included. My position has been unique in that I have had responsibilities across multiple roles, and had a say in my duties after going full-time. I have worked hard and my work has been recognized and rewarded every step of the way with recognition, gifts, kind words, and, at times, encouragement. The work culture in my division was very diverse, easy-going, understanding, and light-hearted. I have made some cherished connections.

job_title: Assistant Professor, Tenure Track in Aurora, CO
pros: Provides great benefits and library services
cons: No support for junior or mid-career faculty, support is caste based and how close you are to the chair, which promotes a non-competitive research environment and more politics and discourages independence. As mentioned in the other reviews for assistant prof, the administration crushes early and mid-career professors as all depends on maintaining continuous funding in a very harsh funding environment. Everything is supported by grants (soft money) with very limited administrative support. All the administration cares for is money, not the well-being of faculty. They create stress and ask you to get help for mental health instead of alleviating stress. Low salaries and a work environment that rewards bullying, harassment and retaliation. No faculty advocates at the AMC campus. All is run by the administration and goes through the administration. The "Professional Office" which is supposed to mitigate complaints does not represent faculty, but rather the administration. As such faculty have no voice. They also would like to advertise AMC as a "breakthrough" campus in research when it only applies for a few labs. They try to hide the many wrongs and appeal to the generosity of donors. There are no subsidies for the use of cores as there are in other top tier universities. The cores are slow since they have no support, parking is expensive.

review_title: Be Cautious of the CU School of Dental Medicine
pros: CU has excellent benefits. CU Anschutz is a beautiful campus.
cons: CU Anschutz is a huge campus with several departments, and I found it interesting that the dental school has not yet been mentioned on glassdoor. My ratings and comments are only in regards to the dental school. There is a high amount of employee turnover from newer employees (2 years or less) trying to come in and make a difference. I believe it is because the bulk of the existing staff and faculty have been there for 4 years to decades, and are stuck doing things "the way they have always been done". They are reluctant to hire new employees. They don't want to be questioned on their out-dated way of doing things. Instead, they find someone internal within the dental school who has already drunk the kool-aid. They want "yes" people. The culture is toxic, and they applaud those who push others way around. There is a lot of bullying here by those with power and are liked by the deans. Once you get on one of the deans' side, you are bullet proof, even if you cut people down daily.

pros:
1) Decent benefits
2) Those I dealt with on the Denver campus were relatively pleasant
3) Once you're in, you're in.
cons:
The Anschutz Medical Campus might very well be home to the largest concentration of passive aggressive people in the world. Watch out. If you don't finagle your way into your department's alpha group, prepare for a miserable time. 

I was blown away by the juvenile behavior on display -- from department heads to hospital representatives to other management. I was stunned by the boorish and insulting actions of so many, from the condescending tone of those I worked with daily to the how-to-do-my-job "benefit lectures" I got from those working outside my department -- under the guise of "friendly advice" of course.

I have two Bachelors of Science , but was made to feel intellectually inferior because I can't add MBA, Ph.D. or MD to my name. Perhaps I should have led my introductory conversation with, "Hi, I'm ___ and I'm in Mensa. My IQ is 152." Maybe then -- and only then --the doctors and MBA types would have respected me.

There were so many bad experiences in just five months, I couldn't take it anymore. I really, really hope I never see any of those people again. 

I had previous experience in an academic setting, so I didn't enter this situation blindly. The climate, culture, and cliques at the Anschutz Medical Campus combined for a five-month experiment I wish I had back.

pros: CU Denver is located right in the middle of downtown Denver which is great if you're a city person. The student population is quite diverse. The facilities are new or are being renovated. The university is growing in size and prestige.
cons: Pay is low and barely comparable to any other institution. Parking is very expensive and no discount for staff. Turn-over is high and there is little to no consistency that I've seen in who remains and goes from one semester to the next. TA's play a large role in the education of the students, but their training and support--thereof--seems lacking university-wide. CU Denver also has an identity crisis, it seems to want to rival CU Boulder, and is willing to sacrifice student life and educational benefits for its expansion dreams. In general the relationship between students and faculty/staff is very subordinate and very lacking in collaboration. Additionally, the departments seems to be much more interested in vying for each others funding, as opposed to collaboration. There is also a very low priority in most colleges in finding employment for students outside of internships, instead the priority is just getting everyone through with a degree.

review_title: Great benefits but can feel limiting depending on your goals
pros: Fantastic benefits package. For exempt staff, you accrue 22 days of PTO and 10 sick days each year, UCD will contribute 10% of your gross salary to your retirement plan each year, and health insurance is good as well. There is also a tuition waiver for 9 credits per year at UCD. Depending on your job and department, management is pretty flexible as far as hours go. Pretty great work/life balance overall. Everyone in my department so far has been wonderful and very invested in developing me as an employee. It's a fairly low pressure and supportive environment.
cons: It is a public institution, so if you are looking for big pay raises or to move up quickly, this may not be the place for you. Advancement happens slowly and it can be frustrating. Just know that in most cases, it's not because your skills aren't needed or valued, it's just the nature of the beast. Many recent grads who start here stay for a few years and then move on.

review_title: Great benefits. Great people. Rough hours
pros: Staff at all levels are passionate, smart, inspirational, and truly care about their field. Faculty and researchers are happy to time time to educate others on what they do, why they do it, and how it'll help mankind someday. The retirement benefits and PTO are outstanding. You receive 11 paid holidays and about three weeks vacation each year. The vacation and sick time rolls over each year.
cons: Rough hours are a sign of the economy across all industries and employer types. You may be assigned the workload of three or more people and are expected to pull it off flawlessly. While supervisors are appreciative and genuinely care, there's nothing they can do given tight budgets from countless cut-backs.

review_title: Good place to learn as PRA or CRC, but pay is below average
job_title: Professional Research Assistant in Aurora, CO
pros: Great place to learn, some PIs really invest in your professional career and are not micro managers. And for the most part PIs are really smart if you are interested in the science. Plenty of resources to learn how to be a good researcher from a scientific and regulatory standpoint. On another note, benefits are great.
cons: Sometimes the work-life balance is not that great and PIs expect you to work long ours. Some departments pay better than others, but for the most part pay for a PRA or CRC is way below national averages. If you are not passionate about the research topic, train here but take your talent to industry, where the pay is far better.

review_title: Treat this as a temporary job!
job_title: Professional Research Assistant in Aurora, CO
pros: Good benefits, and generous vacation an sick leave
cons: The Professional Research Assistant position is a dead end job. The pay is horrible, and it is very difficult to get a raise or any kind of promotion. They make the Senior Professional Research Assistant position almost unattainable. This notwithstanding, supervisors often expect PRAs to work overtime/weekends. The only things that increases with my experience is my work load and responsibilities. Although, they offer generous vacation and sick leave I rarely get to use it. If you accept a position as a Professional Research Assistant with The University of Colorado, have an exit strategy. You will gain valuable research experience, start planning to use it elsewhere because you will not be rewarded here.

review_title: 4 years experience as an Administrative Assistant in a healthcare setting.
job_title: Client Care AideII in Denver, CO
pros: Job security is the best "pro" here. Enjoy being considered a state employee and all the benefits that come with that, including paid holidays, sick time and the amount of vacation received.
cons: The biggest downfall is when the state is in a financial crunch we feel it. It had been many years since a cost of living raise and when we did get one it was almost more insulting than not getting one at all. Didn't mind too much having to pay an extra 2.5% into the retirement fund, but would also like to be able to get that back without having to pay penalties for doing so. Should it really fall on the employees to fix the poor budget planning of the state? I think not!!

review_title: Good place to start a career before continuing education. Don't stay too long.
job_title: Professional Research Assistant in Aurora, CO
pros: The benefits are great.  I only pay $30 a month for both health and dental insurance.  The campus is also very new and will be beautiful when it is complete.  I would also say that most of the professors that work there are nice.  I think some research assistants have considerable time time with nothing to do, which good be beneficial if you are studying.
cons: Can be very boring.  If you don't have an advanced degree don't expect to work on exciting research projects.  It can be a good motivator to go back to school and get a PhD or change career field altogether if you think that you do not have the stomach for it.

pros: People care deeply about the students and are actively working on all kinds of projects to increase student success. Amazing time off (22 days per year) and retirement matching (10%).  The benefits make it hard to leave. The lack of a for-profit environment lets people focus on what matters instead of revenue.
cons: No merit raises on salary, just the annual cost of living which is depending on annual review.  Not a lot of growth because people never leave and new positions are rarely created.  Since benefits are so good, salary is very low compared to private sector. Benefits don't quite make up for the salary difference in the private sector for the highly skilled positions like tech. Also, change moves incredibly show here except the few areas where efforts are being created to improve graduation rates. The back offices don't like change.

job_title: Professional Research Assistant in Aurora, CO
pros: If you have a good boss (PI), then you should find it being a pretty fulfilling overall.
cons: But you will have very little work-life balance since it is research.  You will be paid very little and it won't really increase like you would expect in industry.  Positions other than lab tech and boss (PI) don't really exist, so you will be paid low for a long time or forever.  You will be under the constant worry that your grants will run out and not find any others to support for a while, causing you to loose your job.  Also hard to watch many of the PIs loose their jobs and can't find work.  It is motivating me to move my skills over to industry since the job outlook in academia is so bad right now.

pros: Beautiful downtown campus, interesting and diverse student body, friendly community, and many excellent scholars and departments
cons: The quality of departments, especially in the social sciences, is extremely uneven, with growth and solid research being done in many of them. Some, however, are stuck in the past and have faculty who did their own PhDs at the same institution and are tenured yet have published very little. Adjuncts who lack job security do the bulk of the teaching and MA students are admitted to the program as a way to make money but without solid training that will help those students find jobs. There is a resistance to accountability and increasing the publishing and research quality of faculty.

pros: Interesting place, active campus, tons going on, opportunities to learn, great faculty and staff, good sick and vacation time policies.
cons: I couldn't afford to eat or pay my bills on the salary there, and I had a Master's degree. No respect for certain departments or certain types of employees, and wealth is highly concentrated at the top. No flexibility in terms of work schedules. We were basically chained to our desks between 8 and 5 and had to make up even 5 minutes of work time as exempt employees. Absurd. Low morale in some departments.

pros: Rewarding in that it is mission driven. You see the direct benefits of your efforts in the students.
cons: Poor treatment of support staff by faculty, pay/benefits are low (especially for classified personnel). Not much to build moral among support staff. Hard work and service not rewarded or acknowledged by immediate supervisors and above. Lack of advancement and professional development opportunity.  Work/life balance extremely inflexible.  Operational systems are outdated.

review_title: OK for entry but not competitive
job_title: Senior Research Assistant in Aurora, CO
pros: Good benefits, lots of vacation time/year
cons: Salaries are ok for entry jobs.  Not competitive for people with seasoned experience in the technical field.  Institution is very poor adopting new or changing technology standards- In fact simply improving my technical skills (SAS, Python, R) and attempts to upgrade the informatics environment was met with strong push back by supervisors.  Non existent opportunities for career advancement in PRA jobs and frustrating salary caps.  Salaries are strongly linked to federal grant funding which is at a historic low currently.

review_title: Trying to be Harvard, but still an underfunded state college
job_title: Associate Professor, MD Pediatrics in Aurora, CO
pros: Most of workers are good
cons:
Underfunded, no state support of university. Researcher needs to bring in all of salary through grants. At Aurora campus, little access to undergraduates and grad students, unless you are a big shot. Administration has problems with in breeding (leaders have only been at that institution), and has issues with young investigators, women and minorities. Look at the faces of the leadership in each school, department and division, mostly white males. 

Not close to mountains. Not good public transport. Parking fees are high. Long drives to affordable housing and good schools..

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Denver, CO
pros: Health insurance, paid time off.
cons: GU team is horrible. Poor onboarding with minimal training - lacks good shadowing. Without prior experience one left to figure things out on their own. Ex-manager never really asked "How are you doing?". Supervisor has temper problems by throwing charts on employee's desk and yelling in front of entire trailer. Team is unsupportive but good at talking crap behind one's back. Millennials that used to work there were immature adults professionals who liked to snitch instead of offering help. Easy set up for a failure and a deck up for removal. Factitious atmosphere, no one can be trusted. No respect. A lot of favoritism including in promotions. Nightmare experience. So disappointed, never want to go back.

review_title: It's what you make of it
pros: Very good benefits, attractive campus, definitely the sort of place that one can stay at for years if so desired. If you're looking for a change but want to remain in the system, you can transfer from place to place in the university and retain your benefits.
cons: Your experience will vary by department which is the case anywhere. There is no required training in how to manage people not just operations so if you don't have an experienced or personable supervisor you may want to start looking into those transfers.

pros: Top 5 largest employers in Colorado. There are four campuses with totally different locations and cultures. You can apply to the campus that better suits your desire of lifestyle and culture.
cons:
You have to have thick skin to work on the Anschutz Medical Campus. It is a tough culture to navigate and work in, unfortunately. 

COS, Denver and Boulder tend to have better cultures, but pay much less than Anschutz.

job_title: Professional Research Assistant in Aurora, CO
pros: Cutting edge research that really is making inroads in medicine that will help patients. Very smart, supportive and talented colleagues. Clean, modern work environment. Very good benefits (ample vacation, generous match on retirement contribution, good health insurance, free university classes). Colorado is a nice place to work, no secret there. I love the work I'm doing and the people I work with.
cons: The pay. It's lower than most of us would like, but unfortunately, medical research is under a lot of pressure due to years of cuts to government funding. Most of my colleagues complain about the low pay, but I think many of them are using this work (rightly) as a resume stepping stone.

review_title: Good benefits and vacation, not best for career growth
pros: Great vacation and sick time - Four weeks a year of vacation. The work/life balance is great and the University is definitely a good place to work if you have a family.
cons: Contrary to the mission of a university, growth and development of employees are not the focus. If you are trying to grow your career, it is not a good place to be. Typically, the associates who work for the University are there for a stable, non-changing job and are unwilling to go above and beyond to make any changes. This stems from leadership and is enforced by the human resource department.

review_title: It was a nice place to work
pros: The benefits are good, especially the state discounts.  This place offers a true work-life balance..
cons: There are a whole lot of "know-it-alls", but not a lot of actual knowing. Information hording is rampant. Management hires based on what they "think" they need instead of actually needs. This creates a environment of boredom and layoffs. Or, environments where people are stagnant and are not accountable for deadlines and such because management does not even know what their employees are "really" doing.

pros: Nice city. Occasional smart students and colleagues.
cons: Management is clueless. The institution may go bankrupt if enrollment drops. Salaries are low. The library, which was bad to begin with, has been gutted. The institution is ruled by a culture of mediocrity and fear. Innovation is stifled. Placemen do best.

job_title: IT Professional II in Aurora, CO
pros: Superb retirement program for exempt professionals. Passionate, caring staff. Free professional development classes through HR. Tuition benefits.
cons: Satisfaction and work-life balance is pockety... some departments are wonderful, while others work their employees to the bone. Of more than 7 years with CU, I only had work-life balance for about 2 of those.

review_title: Higher Education is a great place to work in the state government in Colorado
job_title: Director of Finance in Aurora, CO
pros: The tuition waiver benefit for 3 classes per year (a great way to complete your master's degree for free).  There is a balance between life and work at the university, without being overly bureaucratic.
cons: Currently, the state is in a pay increase freeze, with no pay increases for the past two years.  Additionally, there is some element of bureaucracy at the university.

pros: It's a strong academic environment, but perhaps a bit narrow in approach. The administrative staff are friendly and always helpful.
cons: Leadership is a bit conservative. Very focused on financial aspects of the research. Promotion is via counting of papers and how many dollars brought in via grants. Innovative research that doesn't fit well within this paradigm doesn't get much support. Support equals "how can we help you get grants", rather than "how can we help you do science". They assume the latter follows the former. Not an unusual approach this day and age and not something they hide, but you should be aware.

pros: Good benefits. Nice people. The sense of title-based entitlement (aka. I'm better than you because I am a director and you are just a manager) is much less. For the most part people feel valued.
cons: You have to cover 100% of your salary from grants (soft money) so of course if you can't then there is an immediate sense of devaluing by admin.

pros: Salary within normal range for my field, excellent affordable health care, national holidays with a few add-ons like New Year's Eve day, 3 weeks paid vacation, 2 weeks paid sick, 4 weeks paid parental leave plus 3-6 months total parental leave, flexible schedules, casual work environment, stable position
cons: Parking on campus is $70/month, raises are 1-3% and not guaranteed annually, there are often people doing subpar work who we must work with and job stability is a con when it comes to subpar workers

pros: Access to cutting edge technology, friendly and supportive colleagues (at least in my department), decent benefits, pre-review grant proposal panels.
cons: Benefits not as good as in Massachusetts, lack of true "university" feel one experiences in a traditional Letters, Arts, and Sciences college.

review_title: Being a TA was exactly what I thought it would be like.
pros: Application was easy and simple, employment was smooth and hassle-free, I didn't have to jump through any hoops, teacher gave clear directions, and UCD paid on time. Generally speaking, everything was as expected.
cons: It was very difficult to be a teacher's assistant and be a student at the same time due to time constraints. I would not recommend being a TA to anybody who is taking more than 12 hours, unless you are a very studious worker, and can afford the time commitment.

pros: Great benefits! Very relaxed environment, and faculty easy to talk to and work with. Great group of people - all willing to work with each other. No one acted better than anyone else (unlike previous situations I had worked in).
cons: Sometimes there is too much red tape from the university to get things done a bit differently/non-traditionally. Not enough accountability of scientific approaches and thought between scientists (senior and junior). There needs to be more journal clubs and more rigorous questioning of people's work at presentations - not to be mean, but to really hold people accountable for their science.

job_title: Professional Research Assistant in Denver, CO
pros: Great vacation/sick leave, 10% contribution by university into your retirement, tuition benefit, flexible schedule
cons: Low pay (be expected to start at very low end of range) and advancement opportunities are extremely limited. Raises are few and far between. You have to pay for parking (as high as $97 per month). Culture needs improvement. No loyalty to lab staff. You are replaceable.

job_title: Human Resources Specialist in Aurora, CO
pros: Benefits are amazing - 22 paid days of vacation, 15 paid days of sick, 10-11 paid days of holidays.  Health insurance and retirement is also amazing.  Lots of opportunities for growth and movement and depending on which department you work for they can be flexible.  Lots of professional development opportunities.
cons: Compensation is typically lower, on average, than the private sector.  Some departments are set in their ways and are not flexible with schedules.  Pay to park, which is around $150/month downtown and $65/month at Anschutz.

review_title: Amazing facility with even better research
job_title: Professional Research Assistant in Aurora, CO
pros: Great opportunities to network with some of the best Principle investigators in the sciences. Great benefits and perks. The rec center is pretty amazing
cons: Not much patience for developing people and no clear guidelines were ever discussed concerning performance and requirements. Only self-driven, motivated people need apply

job_title: Professional Research Assistant in Aurora, CO
pros: CU has great benefits.  Insurance plans are cheap, you can accumulate a lot of vacation, and retirement matching is high.
cons:
Parking costs are insane and salary is low compared to other institutions.  The title "Professional research assistant" means so many different things on campus.  A professional research assistant can be anything from a data manager, to basic science research, to clinical research, to research nurse, etc.

Hard to get more than a 2% raise unless you move departments.

review_title: My view of my last 9 years there is skewed by having worked alone.  Maybe it could have been different.
job_title: IT Professional II in Denver, CO
pros: Flexible management.  Downtown Denver can be an interesting place.  Variety of work.  P.E.R.A. is a defined benefit plan and was a very good long-term investment for me.
cons: Software development is very informal.  The stovepipe model is used: seldom do people from different projects collaborate.

pros: There is great research at the University of Denver. Mentorship is really hit or miss, seems like you have to try harder to find a good mentor here than other places. The Postdoc Association is pretty active and puts on a lot of good programming - social events, research days, workshops for resumes and grants, lectures on alternative careers and what to do after the postdoc.
cons: Pay isn't great. School of Pharmacy in particular will pay you as little as possible. No retirement benefits for postdocs.

job_title: Medical Student Preceptor Coordinator in Aurora, CO
pros: The retirement benefits are good. Some of the employees are good to work with.
cons: Your work environment depends on the doctor who supervises you.  Some of the younger doctors operate very old school; arrogant, abusive, full of themselves, dictatorial.  A few are more progressive.  They demand complete compliance from you.   Coworkers are competitive and will throw you under the bus without giving it a thought.  The culture encourages this. This is a dead end job, there is no room to grow. If you want a career in higher ed, work in advising, career counceling, grant writing, etc or any department that you don't need specialized degree in order to become director or asst. director.

review_title: Was a a great job to have while attending classes during last year of BA program.
job_title: Lab Monitor/IT Administrative in Denver, CO
pros: Co-workers were helpful to one another, atmosphere was relaxed and not too stressful. Manager of my particular dept. was excellent and knew exactly what needed to be done.
cons: Certain faculty/professor expectations of IT dept. was somewhat high and unrealistic at times. Would ask things of work/study students like tech support and troubleshooting at inappropriate times (i.e. during class hours and not during staffed hours).

pros: Variety of tasks to do and the pay is pretty decent. Other career opportunities are available within the university if you can get through the door to another college or department.
cons:
Have to go through a lot of steps for HR related changes. 
HR and Finance system changes created a lot of issues.

pros: If you are seeking to build your career and you need a place to start, CU Denver is a great place to work. However, once you get a few years of experience under your belt it may be time to move on (see cons).
cons: CU Denver doesn't offer a lot of opportunity to move up and their salaries are not competitive with other companies.

review_title: Great balance between government security and private industry innovation
job_title: Director of Finance in Aurora, CO
pros:
Great retirement benefits
40-45 hour work week
Great healthcare plans starting within 30 days of hire date
22 days of vacation with immediate accrual
Growing interest by senior leadership in developing and innovating across the campus
Change from bureaucratic staff to more innovative and dynamic staff over the last 5 years
cons:
It's still a large institution with some bureaucratic elements
Movement between schools or departments is needed to get promotion
Pay is typically below private industry

pros: There are lots of really smart people working on campus. The benefits are good. Some of the buildings are nice.
cons: Pay is below what you will find in the private sector. There are no incentive or bonus plans for regular staff. No real training opportunities, you have to move around departments to get a promotion.

pros: If you're an IT person looking for a work where you can save up and retire ; or if you want to learn technology without the pressure of the business world this place is ok for you.
cons: The culture is the biggest con. The environment is so political and uncollaborative. You have to cover your back all the time - even among the same team. The management is manipulative & bottomline,  always wins. There are no trainings. And lastly, it seems people here do a lot of things for job security. To top all that the pay is very low and the increase is negligible.

review_title: SQUID LAB a wonderful experience for intern or RA
pros: Many opportunities to learn about lab work, high-sensitivity measurements, how to write up a proper lab book.  Learn how to work individually and as part of a multi-disciplinary team.  Monday morning meetings to explain to your lab what you did all week and what the results mean.
cons: Funding can sometimes be a problem.  If there is not enough funding, people have to work as volunteers.  Funding decreases can mean fewer projects.

job_title: Senior Career Counselor in Denver, CO
pros: They pay you more if you have kids. Good health insurance
cons: Too many meetings. Slow paced. Everything needs approval. They evaluate staff from a deficit perspective. Never promote. Most department heads are lousy at management. They like to talk about how diverse they are, but do nothing to actually be inclusive. Constant reorganizations and cuts to funding.

pros: Excellent benefits include significantly subsidized health insurance and and a10% match to a 5% of salary into a defined contribution pension plan.
cons: Salary increases are extremely limited by state budget priorities and there is little incentive to be entrepreneurial in improving the system, outside the self interest in getting research funding.

job_title: Business Services Manager in Aurora, CO
pros: Great benefits, easy to move from job to job within the University
cons: Dysfunction from the top, incompetent leaders are rewarded by allowing them to move up, no innovation, no mission statement within departments, no vision, huge turnover.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Denver, CO
pros: Flexible schedule, great support from staff and department. Resources needed are readily available, and tuition is paid for. Tuition is paid for up front, making salary package much better.
cons: Parking is expensive and public transportation still requires a 5-10 minute walk to office. My building is being renovated and will the project will be continuing after my graduation.

job_title: Senior Professional Research Assistant in Aurora, CO
pros: Lots of flexibility. Pleasant co-workers.
cons: Low salary for years of experience.  Finding good management is key to a happy work place no matter how much you get along with your co-workers.

review_title: Good place to work if you like part-time teaching. Pay good.
pros: Getting experience teaching at a four year university. Excellent experience in running a classroom - little or no interference from supervisors/bureaucracy. Looks great on resume.
cons: If you are not tenure track, you are at the mercy of academic politics/seniority. Not a place to hang your hat for a long time. You are a contractor.

pros: Provides good benefits and fair starting pay. With working here you get experience with a large institution with a well-known reputation that can lead to future opportunities and good networking.
cons: With working with a partially state funded institution there is lots of red tape to cross before seeing changes occur and bureaucratic headaches to deal with. Departments and divisions can be isolated as to create really great working atmospheres or not the best working atmospheres.

pros: The university is located in the heart of Denver. The campus is growing and more focus is being dedicated to research. Administration is supportive of faculty and the quality of the student body is improving over time.
cons: Resources are more limited compared to CU Boulder and there only a handful of Ph.D. programs and access to research assistants. The relationship with the medical campus is still not strong and the systems across the two campuses need to  be better integrated.

pros: Worked at laboratory on Anschutz (Aurora) campus. Benefits were good, people were awesome.
cons: Rarely had opportunity to take time off. It was clinical laboratory with not enough staffing to allow for individuals to take the amount of time-off given. No career path. UofColorado is state job, so compensation was much BELOW market. Management kept promising a pay review, however never started. I did y own pay review and realized how under paid I was - found similar job at 25% higher pay.

review_title: don't expect much from your managers
pros: inexpensive health care, vision, dental, and retirement plans; reputable name; nice location
cons: HR says things like "I am just a resource, a human resource"; complaints get swept under the rug; passive aggressive upper management; no room for growth; and the most common complaint is that upper management pushes people out if they speak up or blow the whistle.

pros:
May work with top-tier researchers
research that benefits others
flexible hours
cons: Felt like a work monkey where the head of the project made you feel like her assistant rather than her collaborator.  Pay in lab I was in SUCKED with no raise for me butyes  for other co-workers that were not pulling their weight.

pros: Metro Denver is the area to be in currently. My current department/lab is well funded. New head of postdoc office is helpful and a great resource here on campus. Active PDA.
cons:
If your interested in getting teaching experience just know you will likely have to find opportunities off campus (ie community colleges or another local college).
Cost of living is quite high, which means the money you make as a postdoc doesn't goes super far, but it is doable.

review_title: Stimulating environment with international, bright co-workers
pros:
Denver i general is a great place to live. Amazing outdoor activities, low cost of living and friendly people.
The university offers a good benefit package, cutting edge technology and friendly people to work with. 
The health science center is located at a suburb of Denver, making housing cost low.
cons:
Salaries are average for the academic sector. 
After graduation from the university the opportunities are a little limited as Denver is not a major city.

review_title: Great University if you choose the right mentor and department
pros: Top notch University; well respected. Excellent research institution if you can find the right mentor.
cons: Lack of clear mission, vision, purpose within certain schools and departments. Extremely competitive for any sort of advancement; beware of the academic road map.

pros: Lots of autonomy to come and go as you want as long the job gets done; pay is average
cons: Leadership is terrible- little to no idea what is going on "in the trenches" of the classroom; little to no feeling of community amongst employees

pros: The team I worked with was phenomenal. The project was designed to do great work in the community and we provided a valuable service! My colleagues were top notch!
cons: The bureaucracy was a deterrent from doing the best that could have been done. There could have been more success if the front line workers could have had the honest backing from the higher ups.

job_title: Professional Research Assistant in Denver, CO
pros: Great working environment, great for independent work while still offering access to others in the field for problem solving. Excellent benefits & HR team
cons: Work schedule flexibility varies by department and job description. Most training specific to each role is learn as you go since no two jobs seem to be alike. Pro/con depending on your work style

review_title: Wonderful research community, but lacks support for young scientists
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Aurora, CO
pros: Approachable scientists of all levels, collaborative environment, cutting edge research, great lifestyle
cons: CU Denver does not have the research facilities larger institutes have, and what we do have costs more. The lack of funding by the state makes it hard to compete for national funding against larger institutes.

job_title: Professional Research Assistant/Clinical Research Coordinator in Denver, CO
pros: Amazing benefits - retirement savings, health insurance, holiday/sick/vacation PTO.
cons: Extremely low pay with difficulty to earn raises. Not truly merit based! Makes you wonder why you work so hard if there's so little chance your compensation can increase by more than 2% annually. Research managers can rise up without much intellect and while playing favorites.

review_title: Long hours, low pay, and no appreciation.
pros: Flexibility, challenging research, and interesting projects. Many interesting colleagues doing good research.
cons: Very low pay, untrained management, lack of focus on safety. Lack of cohesive culture focused on rewarding employees for good work. Long work hours expected without compensation, or even appreciation of your efforts.

pros:
- Flexible hours, works with you around midterms and finals.
- Many different work opportunities around, fitting different majors.
- Consistent raises (if you do a good job), including minimum raises every year.
cons:
- Internal cattiness between departments
- The process of becoming a work-study/student hourly worker could be too confusing for most people. I think more people would take advantage of the flexibility of this kind of work, if they were more informed.

pros: Challenging academic school and great research for cancer. Pay is pretty decent.
cons: Cancer research is good, but thats about it. Also the cancer research is very narrowly focused to signal pathways. Yes they play an important role, but for something as broad as cancer there need to be different approaches.

job_title: Political Science Instructor in Denver, CO
pros: Great employer that recognizes the necessity to evolve, both as a university and community organization. The university's resources continue to grow, and it is reflected by the level of tenured professors now employed by the university.
cons: The downsides are the same as most public universities'.  They are struggling to meet the increasing student populations, and it seems to be OK with the administration to continue to exploit students' pocket books.

review_title: Great place to work if you want to be in academia
pros: Great health benefits, Careers in Science Club, postdoc association, awesome discounted gym (health and wellness center), flexible hours, excellent lab resources, excellent core facilities, great opportunities of collaboration,  good seminar series, you get to live in amazing Colorado
cons: Lack of funding, cost of parking, no tuition benefits for postdocs, the usual academia stuff (low salaries, under appreciation), not the best neighborhood

pros:
-Cheapest insurance I've ever had that actually covered things, and I even worked at an insurance company.
-Decent PTO
-Automatic 7% retirement contribution from CU Medicine after a year of employment
-Nice building
-Great staff
cons: Too much busywork. Some of the managers will overload you with work. Honestly it just depends on getting in the "right" department.

pros: A large University setting with a lot of great resources and a new campus.  There are a bunch of really great labs doing a wide variety of research and clinical work.  The actual like-ablity of each job would depend on the individual lab, but most seem like great spots.
cons: Being in a pretty lousy part of Aurora makes living or eating near campus dicey.

review_title: good PTO, labs run independently, but good Uni framework in place
pros: benefits, especially PTO, is excellent, pay is fairly competitive, flexible schedule based on lab work
cons: I'm being held to a glass ceiling based on formal training, so i'm topped out at the amount I can make with a B.S. , which is bs. Culture changes lab by lab, so be sure you're in a good situation at the personal level

review_title: refers to AMC not any other campus
pros: The view from AMC's research towers is beautiful, especially the sunsets.
cons: Cost of living in Denver is $$$, lack of career counseling or mentorship unless you go out and find it yourself, work life balance really depends upon the lab you are in, basically each lab is a micro work environment with a different boss and culture so you could get really lucky or not.

pros: Although I have just started working at the Denver campus, it's been a great experience so far.  Management seems to really value a work-life balance.  They appear to have great training and have all the processes documented very well.  They have great benefits.
cons: It might be a little difficult to move up within the department or get larger raises compared to more of the "corporate" world."

pros: Very good benefits and a stability
cons: Very low salaries compared to private sector. Significant amount of red tape to work through at all levels.

job_title: Academic Advisor Administrator/Career Counselor in Baytown, TX
pros: Great people to work with. Outstanding benefits. Great location and environment. I enjoyed my time at the University of Colorado Denver. Maybe I will return there again one day.
cons: I did not have any issues with the university. everyone was nice and helpful. I enjoyed my time there . I have kept in contact with my co workers and hope to see them again one day.

pros: CU does a great job of aligning business operations policy and procedure.  Made it very easy and clear what was expected and how to work within the system.
cons: Getting in and out of downtown Denver, especially in bad weather.  The cost of parking.  The main campus in Boulder thinks they're better, which is ridiculous - it's the same institution.

pros: There are some wonderful colleagues to work with.  There is much in the way of innovative scientific research occurring on campus.  The health benefits are good, and there is a lot of vacation and sick leave.
cons: Employees are largely responsible for their salary.  This is largely dependent on federal grants getting funded, so is not secure in a long-term view.

review_title: Funding makes this University Go Round
pros: The faculty are great! They are very supportive of each other and the students.
cons: If you don't have current big federal funding, you are subject to the whims of the administration- regardless of funding record.

review_title: Job satifaction highly dependant on immediate supervisor
job_title: Pofessional Research Assistant in Aurora, CO
pros: Good benefits and paid time off.
cons: How good your work experience and pay is depends on the individual supervisor. Ditto for work culture and coworkers. Pay generally a lot  lower than industry and biotech.

pros: Convenient, flexible hours and schedule. Located on campus. Low stress. Get to know professors and university staff on a more personal level.
cons: Low pay and little opportunity for advancement. Day time hours only, which makes working enough hours difficult. Not mentally challenging..

pros: Flexible schedule.  Cool campus right in downtown Denver.  My team was very supportive and was interested in creating a good culture and finding the right people.
cons: Was not a fan of the way the new Dean of my college treated people.  Everyone - regardless of race, gender, degree, social status - **Everyone** deserves your attention and respect.

pros: PhD programs here are really hard but hopefully you become a better scientist at the end of grueling 5 years.
cons: Departments are too focused on funding. Unfortunately that leads to a lack of supportive environment for students. Students are only treated as cheap labor to get the research done.

pros: Depending on department, great faculty, laid back work environment, and a care for employees. Nice bump in salary with education credentials.  Health benefits are pretty good.
cons: Depending on department, a great deal of mismanagement, micromanagement, and general lack of care for employees.  As with academia, there can be a lot of red tape and hoop jumping and politics.

review_title: Earned my Doctorate at the Anschutz Medical Campus - Great place to work
pros:
Cross-departmental collaboration is exceptional.  
People are passionate about the science and not cagey as in some other institutions.   
Your PI and Thesis Adviser will make or break the experience for you, so choose wisely.
Facilities are very good.
cons: Like any university, its all about getting the grant money.

review_title: Great experience as a full time student.
pros:
Convenient location (on campus).
Flexible hours (work between classes or when available).
Environment is good for developing yourself professionally.
cons: Compensation is a little low. Might need to supplement with student loans if getting yourself through school on your own.

job_title: Physical Assistant in University of Colorado, CO
pros: Majority of people working here are committed to caring for patients and are team players
cons: Income is below average, though Colorado income for mid-levels as a whole is one of the lowest in the United States.

review_title: Good place for the long term
pros: Benefits are good. Once you are in the system, you have a higher chance of moving around to different career opportunities as they like to hire from within. Pay is okay, could be better. Great training and learning opportunities.
cons: Most departments don't work well together which makes it hard to get things accomplished.

pros:
Lots of opportunities
Strong networking
I'm able to have a flexible schedule, which adds to my work/life balance.
Create vacation and retirement benefits
cons: This is a large system that requires working with several different entities.  As such it can be challenging to move forward on different projects depending on the information and resources needed.

pros: Decent benefits, 401k matching, flexibility working arrangement available, 9 free credits per year, relatively cheap parking and bus pass
cons: Competing responsibilities, multiple people that the position must report to, faculty are catered to unapologetically. pay not match COL increase

pros: Great if you are looking to go to a PhD program
cons: Under-appreciated by the faculty members. If lectures ever get behind you have to fill in those missing gaps to the students in your lab during recitation. More than likely students will blame you for the harsh grading policies that you have to adhere to.

job_title: Computer Lab Assistant in Denver, CO
pros: This is a pretty cushy student job. I just sit in the language lab and work on homework and get paid for it. In fact, I'm getting paid to write this right now.
cons: The pay is low. But what do you expect for getting paid to watch a computer lab while you do homework?

review_title: Nice and warm people to work with
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Denver, CO
pros: They work like a family and what else should I say when I say the word "family"
cons: Not much career growth and the benefits were not much for a part-time

job_title: Professional Research Assistant in Aurora, CO
pros: Fun job.  Great benefits.  More vacation time than you know what to do with.
cons: The university is a complete bureaucracy.  It seems the lab has to continually fight them at every step.  My boss has the money to raise my salary and would, but he can't because of university policy.

review_title: Great place to work in Colorado
pros:
Great benefits
Collaborative environment
Diverse workplace
Lots of interaction with other departments and interdepartmental collaboration
cons:
Not as much funding as schools in other states - so raises are less frequent and there's not as much budget for professional development and training

Like any state school - politics slows down progress and improvements to processes

review_title: Good climate. Good Benefits. Meaningful work.
job_title: Professional Research Assistant in Denver, CO
pros: Good academic environment.  It has a climate that appreciates learning.  The work you do is meaningful and has purpose.  Benefits allow you to have a satisfying work-life balance.
cons: Like any academic institution, there is always a hierarchy.  You have to juggle egos now and again.

pros: Independent work hours that fir my class schedule.
cons: Minimal contact with my superior and had to ask business services for access to office with hardcopies
